720732f.text:
95, 97, 101 King Street, north side, adjoining the N.W. corner of Hudson Street. The building in the center was originally the Wesley Methodist Episcopal Church, during the 1850's; but it has long since ceased to be a church. It will be demolished shortly
before 1910.
June 4, 1904.
Brown Brothers.
720732f.folder: King Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY

720731f-a.text:
84, 94 King Street, east of, adjoining, and at the S.E. corner of Hudson Street. No. 94 is the King Street side of the Evening Graphic Building; No. 84 is a garage, less than six years old as shown here. In the foreground is part of the clearing for the new United States Appraisers' Stores (see Varick Street).
December 7, 1927.
P. L. Sperr.
720731f-a.folder: King Street & Hudson Street, Manhattan, NY

720524f-a.text:
Excavation for the new Standard Statistics Building, Hudson Street, west side, from King Street to Charlton Street, a
side view from King Street.
April 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
720524f-a.folder: Hudson Street & King Street, Manhattan, NY

720526f-a.text:
Evening Graphic Building, Hudson Street, east side, from King Street to Charlton. In the foreground is part of the excavation for the Standard Statistics Building.
April 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
720526f-a.folder: Hudson Street & King Street, Manhattan, NY

720531f-a.text:
Hudson Street, at King Street, seen from cleared S.W. corner (the Standard Statistics Building excavation). On the N.E. corner is part of the new United States Appraisers' Stores building, now two years old, which fills the entire block bounded by Hudson, King,
Varick, and West Houston Streets.
April 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
720531f-a.folder: Hudson Street & King Street, Manhattan, NY

720533f-a.text:
Hudson Street, east side, from Ling Street to West Houston (formerly Hammersley) Street, inclusive, showing the Hudson Street side of the two year old U. S. Appraisers' Stores building, which occupies the entire block. The view is from Charlton Street across the excavation on the west side of Hudson Street where the Standard Statistics Building is about to rise. Notice the pedestrians on Hudson Street, at the right, stopping to watch the workmen in the excavation.
april 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
720533f-a.folder: Hudson Street & King Street, Manhattan, NY

720733f-b.text:
(1)
113 to 95 King Street, north side, west of and towards Hudson Streeu, seen fron. the clearing on the south side where the Stand: Statistics Building is to be erected. Nos. 109, 107, 105, 103 are the four old houses with dormer windows; No. 101 has a flat roof. No. 95 adjoins 363 Hudson Street, the corner building. The one-story garage and lunch room at 97-99 King Street is less than ten years old, it occupies the former site of the Wesley
Methodist Episcopal Church.
April 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
99 to 121 King Street, north side, from west of Hudson Street to the N.E. corner of Greenwich Street, a view taken on the same day as the above and largely overlapping it. No. 115-121 King
Street is the paper box factory at the left.
April 23, 1930.
720733f-b.folder: King Street & Hidson Street, Manhattan, NY

720733f-a.text:
(1)

733360f-b.title: Thanksgiving ragamuffins, No.31-33.
733360f-b.text:
(1)
Thanksgiving Ragamuffins, 1933, No. 31. A 1ittle girl applying lipstick, at 367 Hdson Street, west side, between King and
West Houston Streets.
November 30, 1933.
L. Sperr.
(2)
No. 32. This one got a very liberal application of lipstick. The location is 381 Hudson Street, in the same block. Notice the NRA Blue Eagle in the window; these had just come in
that fall.
Novomber 30, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(3)
No. 33. In the same block, a group including the little tyke
shown in No. 32.
November 30, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

720525f-a.text:
Hudson Street, west side, from Ring Street to Charlton, showing the entire block demolished early in 1935 to make room for the new Standard Statistics Building. Nos. 387361, at the S. W. corner of Ping Street, are three frame houses practically merged into one; and No. 353, adjoining, is a frame house with brick facing. On these buildings one dormer window can be counted for each house number (odd) from 353 to 361, inclusive.
August 1e,1927.
P. L. Sperr.
720525f-a.folder: Hudson Street & King Street, Manhattan, NY

720532f-b.text:
Hudson Street, west side, north from and including King Street, and west on the latter to the paper box factory at No. 115-121
King Street.
April 23, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
Hudson Street,West Side and south Houston from Clarkson Streets.
September 24th,1938
P.L.Sperr,
(3)
Hudson Street,West side from Houston to King Street.
October 2,1938.
P.L.Sperr.
